body.content: A case study of this portfolio

This project is in fact the portfolio that you are currently looking at. I will be adding, in the near future, a small case study about how I designed and created this portfolio, looking into some of the UX choices, technologies used, etc. I feel it will be a useful example of my skills as it is something that I have, obviously, had complete control over.
About Resident Evil

Towards the end of my tenure at Teads, we were briefed by our immediate manager that we should use any down time among client projects to start creating more expressive examples of the sort of work we could do for clients - more interactive creatives such as more product details, elements that interact with the time-stamp of a video, small games, etc. This was the result of my downtime.

content.alt: Screenshot of the games opening instruction carousel
Screenshot of the game mid play, showing remaining ammunition and 1 zombie enemy on screen
Screenshot of the game mid play, showcasing the enemy attack graphic
Screenshot of the game mid play, showing remaining ammunition and 2 standard zombie enemies on screen
A screenshot of the game mid action
A screenshot of the game mid action

body.content: Tech and responsibilities overview

I was the designer and developer for this small game working with HTML, CSS3 and Vanilla JavaScript. The graphics themselves were stills taken from the actual game. I spent approximately a week, still fairly new to more in-depth JavaScript at the time, trying to create a game that would then be incorporated into a standard Teads advert template - the end screen would advertise the product release date, links to the official site, replay or share the game, etc. I worked to create a responsive game using standard HTML elements that would be injected into and positioned around the play area, in this case behind the table as well as either side of it (see graphic examples below). The hit-box for each enemy is a transformed element that corresponds to the position and shape of the relevant appendage; arm, leg, head, etc. each of which, when clicked effect the damage applied to an enemy, as well as flagging the area hit for the score board at the end of the game.

The game features things such as a variable difficulty that increases as the players score increases, randomised position of enemies, be that around the level itself within a specific set of areas that surround the table, scaling the graphic appropriately based on their position with CSS and appropriate flags, randomising the position of the graphic within that set area, so no two enemies should theoretically ever exactly overlay one another. Their health was also randomised within a specific range based on the enemy type, to give a further challenge to players. I added the ability to replenish the players health via a collectable that appears on the table as a random chance drop by every defeated enemy - they will sit there indefinitely until a player clicks on them - again, spawning within a set area at random positions and scaling appropriately.

content.alt: Screenshot of the game mid play, showing remaining ammunition and 1 zombie enemy on screen
Screenshot of the game mid play, showcasing the enemy attack graphic
Screenshot of the game mid play, showing remaining ammunition and 2 standard zombie enemies on screen
A screenshot of the game mid action
A screenshot of the game mid action

body.content: As well as the base game itself, I created a few reusable "components" such as an infinite, scalable carousel for the games opening instructions as well as experimentiht with spritesheets to save on requests when loading the games graphics. I also, at least for the desktop version of the game, included an audio engine that played music as well as sound effects reflecting the action happening on screen such as the firearm sound effects, enemy attacks, etc. While the code within this project is, even by standards of the time very messy, it was my first project working heavily with JavaScript and is something I am still proud of, despite its flaws.
About Teads

Teads, previously Ebuzzing, is an advertising company specialising in video advertising, primarily their proprietary native video format. Teads native video format injects video advertisements within the content of the website itself creating "minimal disruption for the end user" while still creating value for the client.
Tech and responsibilities overview

I worked as a designer and developer for varying types of mobile and desktop advertisements, as well as responsive creatives, working with animation frameworks, pure CSS3 animations and various elements of video implementation and tracking to form submissions, to create compelling adverts for clients.

content: Created templates for basic carousel micro-sites and image "takeovers".
Varying degree of complexity responsive micro-sites for numerous products.

body.content: My role at Teads was that of developer, primarily for mobile creatives however I also worked with desktop scale micro-sites, created responsive advertisements that could be used across the board and also static graphics for video content surrounds. Tech wise I worked with Flash on occasion but was hired to allow Teads to transition more heavily into HTML5 creatives, especially due in part to the slow removal of Flash support from browsers that had begun at the time.

The majority of the micro-sites were usually some variety of a content carousel allowing for the inclusion of tracked video as well as more in depth content and CTA's. Sometimes clients would come to us with a design and assets and other times we would pitch differing designs for the client to choose from/adjust to their needs before supplying us the required assets.

For these types of creative, I built a boilerplate that implemented in-depth tracking for videos included within the creative (that could scale to the number of videos included) that had unique identifiers for each media. This could tie into a Google Analytics account if the client wished but was primarily linked to the internal Teads tracking software, recording things such as whether a video was played, paused (for how long and how often), whether the user trigged the pause or whether it was because they had changed into a different page of the carousel, timestamps, etc. I often acted as as development support for other branches of Teads with my knowledge of JavaScript and GreenSock and, quite often as well, responsive elements of advertisements, offering knowledge and tips frequently to the Spanish and German team.

When working with the mobile "footer" creatives, the design concept had the same approach with clients either having something in mind or seeking designs, however, they were always static content. The creative usually involved two "pages" of content that animated between one another with animations throughout. These animation timelines were handled by working with GreenSock animation library to ensure the order and timing of elements animating.

Footer banners varied between a static graphic that the advertising framework slide in from the bottom of the screen or included some minor animations, such as the OKA graphics that slid each furniture item in before fading the text, etc.

As we pitched design ideas to clients as well as the requirement to assemble the base assets that they would supply to us, I worked quite heavily with Adobe Photoshop. We always made sure to have a professional structure to documents so that changes could be made easily and quickly by anyone else in the team making use of smart objects, layers and groups as well as documenting anything of note in an accompanying README text file, all of which were stored on an internal network drive.

As the layout of these "takeovers" was standardised to fit copy and logos within the smallest common screen size (at the time, this was still 1920 X 1080), we used a template that was shared on the company dashboard. After using this once or twice, I noticed that the template was outdated with the current build of the advertising platform software leading to the size and position of the video varying from it's supposed location on the creative. Once cleared by my manager, I recreated the Photoshop template file with the now correct layer positions, appropriate naming, guidelines, etc, which was then uploaded to replace the old template on the internal resource centre.

body.content: About Movidiam

Movidiam is designed to be a one stop shop for everything one might require during a media production project, be that talent, asset sharing or even management of the project at hand. It features social network profiling for freelancers to display their work, write blogs, post status updates as well as feature contact information for potential clients. This profiling also links into a map-based search system, allowing users to enter a search term such as "Camera operator in New York" which will then supply a list of results matching that criteria, in a similar manner to Airbnbs search page. Movidiam also offer a briefing system where users can contact Movidiam to request a specific type or multiple types of users to help them creating a production - the chosen responses coming from the 20K+ freelancers registered to the service.
Tech and responsibilities overview

I worked as a front-end developer for Movidiam working from a junior role through to senior over the course of 4 years, managing a small team of varying size as the project progressed. I helped shape the UI and UX of the platform through my experience and understanding of good user experience principals and worked with Sketch and Photoshop to convey these processes. I championed new technologies and methodologies to follow to enable a beautiful and functional interface while keeping the codebase reusable and concise. I worked on areas from email templates, Salesforce pages and the product itself, as well as an internal admin dashboard, all of which were accomplished with technologies such as Ember.js, Ember Data, Ember Animation/Liquid Fire, Docker and other core web-dev technologies. I worked with the back-end developers on a daily basis with REST API's and had some hand in server management with AWS S3 and EC2 instances.

From initially being hired as a junior front-end developer, I was quickly promoted to senior front-end developer, managing a small, establishing the codebase standards, implementing the BEM naming methodology as well as introducing Sass to the production pipeline.

I worked as a front-end developer for Movidiam working from a junior role through to senior over the course of 4 years, managing a small team of varying size as the project progressed. I helped shape the UI and UX of the platform through my experience and understanding of good user experience principals and worked with Sketch and Photoshop to convey these processes. I championed new technologies and methodologies to follow while keeping the codebase reusable and concise. I worked on areas from email templates, Salesforce pages and the product itself, as well as an internal admin dashboard, all of which were accomplished with technologies such as Ember.js, Ember Data, Ember Animation/Liquid Fire, Docker and other core web-dev technologies. I worked with the back-end developers on a daily basis with REST API's and had some hand in server management with AWS S3 and EC2 instances. Other duties included:

content: Led a small team of developers working within an Agile development process with daily scrums and retrospectives once a feature was live.
Worked with the Design team to vet designs against potential web technology limitations as well as help transition these designs to a responsive layout.
Created page templates for Salesforce which integrated submission forms and were consistent with the main website.
Developed responsive HTML email templates which improved click-through rates by an average of 20%.

body.content: UX and UI design

I also worked with the UI and UX design of numerous pages, aiding in the design and establishment of a brand / style guide for interactions, UI navigation element placement and appearance as well as full page designs. I was also instrumental in redesigning the appearance and interactions of key components following material design heuristics, and global elements like spacing between elements, standardising the appearance of secondary informational elements (such as using a specific grey for things like subtitles on cards, date time elements. Over time as we rolled out these sweeping changes the site as a whole became much more intuitive and we were praised by numerous users for the clean appearance of the site and by reinforcing users expectations of interactivity with the interface, how much easier the site was to use.

I worked with the designers before building an email template that rendered consistently as possible across devices / email clients. We gradually improved this base template with more accessibility features such as adding applicable role attributes , etc. With each redesign, we also created more complex layouts such as implementing a responsive layout for desktop clients, as well as A/B testing with adjusting the position and appearance of elements such as the CTA, spacing, element orders, etc. resulting in high click-through conversion rates for the majority of emails.

As well as the main site, I worked on other projects such as the internal management dashboard (only accessible to our team that allowed them to moderate comments on the site, adjust users tiers, select users work for the community featured pages, create newsletters, etc.) the Salesforce pages that the sales team used for white-papers, etc. as well as email templates for differing functionality (registration emails, notifications as well as newsletter templates).

I worked with the lead back-end developer to create a series of basic customisable templates for various sections that could be frequently used together interchangeably to create a range of design layouts. We then created  WYSIWYG interface for the Sales staff to create a complete printout of the markup they could then paste into Salesforce, thus allowing them to create professional pages with a look consistent with the main Movidiam site without the need for technical web development knowledge.
About loveholidays

Loveholidays, "the fastest growing online travel agency in the UK", is a UK based package holiday website. Loveholidays specialises in allowing users to search without a specific date or destination in mind, but rather, by a series of different filters such as budget, board basis, temperature, etc. as well as offering flexible payment methods for customers wanting to extend the payment duration.
This was my first experience of working with React and Redux as well as technologies like styled components (CSS in JS) and yarn, once we transitioned to it's use over NPM towards the end of 2019.

body.content: Tech and responsibilities overview

At Loveholidays, I worked as a part of the "experiments team" as a front-end developer. The experiments team is a sub-division of the main web development team that focused solely on AB experiments to UI and UX tweaks throughout the site. The experiments team was broken down into further sub-divisions (internally referred to as pods), each consisting of a team lead, a QA, a UX designer and two more front-end developers. During my tenure at Loveholidays, I was promoted to pod lead of "Team Vikings" where I was managing the teams overall goals per week, assessing new AB experiments technical feasibility with the UX designer as well as tutoring more junior members of the team. The team was also charged with having a weekly "ideas session" to come up with new ideas for experiments that we could roll out the following week once a ticket had been written up after the session.

Amongst my other duties, I began working closely with the experiments team lead to attempt to establish a component library as well as working with the overall UX team to also establish a proper design system that we could gradually roll out across the site. Due to the rapid expansion as well as the rigorous AB testing that had occurred across the site, there were lots of UI inconsistencies as well as lots of non DRY markup / code and we decided that we should try and clear up some of the technical debt that had been amassed now that the company had reached more stable footing in regards to growth.
UX and UI design

Thanks to my previous experience at Movidiam working heavily with the UI and UX, I was able to work closely with our pods UX designer and suggest numerous AB tests to hopefully improve the user experience across the site. As we worked mostly on the home and search results page (areas of the site were loosely designated to specific pods) we experimented with minor things such as adjusting the information on the cards and within the hotel details modal, to completely redesigning the results cards. A number of the tests that we pushed through from start to finish had a high "win rate" with regards to conversion improvement across the board.

I also, as a part of the component library  / design system, helped to standardise things like an accessible click area for links and buttons, increasing font sizes and iconography, creating a system to fully standardise the icons and their usage throughout the site while removing icons that were superfluous so that their meaning could be learned by users (an example of this is whether a result was flight only or hotel and flight booking).

body.content: About Geeiq
I have only recently just started working at Geeiq as of May 2020
Geeiq is a gaming based data anaylsis tool enabling brands actionable insights for optimising strategy in regards to marketing to audiences of esports teams, streamers and tournaments.
